title: A.I. Validates What Jesus Knew About the Book of Daniel | Marking the End Times
description:
I want to share a stunning discovery today that drives a nail in the coffin of 
one of the most persistent attacks against Bible prophecy. For almost 1,700 
years, since a pagan philosopher named Porphyry in the 3rd century AD, 
many scholars have claimed the Book of Daniel was written after the events 
it “predicts” already happened. They call this ex eventu or “after the fact,” 
claiming Daniel is really history masquerading as prophecy.
This matters enormously because Daniel is the key prophetic book in the 
Old Testament—often called the Old Testament Book of Revelation. But 
researchers using AI machine learning called “Enoch” have conclusively 
dated a Dead Sea Scroll copy of Daniel (manuscript 4Q114) to be at least 
100 years earlier than previously believed—placing it firmly in the 3rd 
century BC. This means Daniel couldn’t possibly have been written in the 
2nd century BC as skeptics have claimed, since we now have copies existing
before those events even occurred! This powerfully supports the traditional 
530 BC date when Daniel himself wrote it in Babylon. Most importantly, 
Jesus Himself confirmed Daniel’s authorship in Matthew 24:15, which 
should settle the issue for all believers.
-------

title: The “Destroy Israel” Clock | Marking the End Times
description:
Today I discuss not the famous Doomsday Clock created by atomic scientists
in 1947, but a far more sinister timepiece—Iran’s “Destroy Israel” Clock 
that sat in Tehran’s Palestine Square until just a few days ago. This massive 
digital billboard counts down the days until September 21, 2040, when 
Iran’s Supreme Leader predicts Israel will cease to exist. The clock displays 
“Only [X] days remaining to the annihilation of Israel” in Farsi, English, and 
Arabic, featuring a Palestinian flag-colored fist punching through an Israeli 
flag.
Israel claims they destroyed this clock in their June 23rd airstrike during 
their twelve-day war with Iran, though Iran disputes this with unverified 
footage. Whether the physical clock survived matters less than what it 
represents—Iran’s doomsday theology remains intact. This isn’t mere 
political rhetoric; it’s apocalyptic ideology woven into their core beliefs 
about the coming of the Mahdi, their hidden twelfth Imam. Iranian 
theologians consistently teach that before the Mahdi appears, there will be 
no Jewish state. This explains why any Middle East peace will be temporary
—Iran will use peaceful periods simply to reload. As Ezekiel 38 prophesies, 
Iran will ultimately be part of the end-times coalition against Israel, making 
their current hatred both predictable and prophetic.
Today I also addressed three important theological questions from 
subscribers. The first asked me to define dispensationalism versus non-
dispensationalism and provide arguments for the dispensational position. 
The second question challenged why we use the word “predict” when 
discussing Bible prophecy, arguing it lacks authority compared to weather 
forecasting and occult predictions, when God’s prophecies are absolute and 
authoritative. The final question referenced a Matt Chandler quote about 
Revelation being given to encourage believers for 2000 years rather than 
just informing about the End Times. These questions touched on 
fundamental issues of biblical interpretation, prophetic terminology, and the
practical relevance of the Bible’s prophetic literature

title: From Palestinian Statehood to the Two Witnesses | Marking the End Times
description:
Today, I examine three interconnected Middle East storylines pointing toward the End Times. First, the mounting pressure for Palestinian statehood recognition, with 146 of 193 UN member nations supporting it and French President Macron leading a UN conference to explore Palestinian state creation. Ambassador Mike Huckabee's controversial suggestion that Muslim countries create a Palestinian state on their territory represents a sharp departure from decades of US policy. Second, President Trump's pressure on Prime Minister Netanyahu to end the Gaza war while blocking Israeli strikes on Iran during ongoing nuclear negotiations. Iran continues its delay tactics while enriching uranium to 60% purity—enough for nine nuclear weapons if enriched further. Third, Iran's claims of possessing Israeli nuclear intelligence and threats to target Israeli sites. These crises are setting the stage for the Antichrist's meteoric rise to solve this diplomatic Rubik's Cube. 

Next, I address the identity and ministry of the Two Witnesses in Revelation 11:3–14. The main questions center on who these witnesses are and when they will minister. I argue they are real people, not symbolic representations, based on their physical actions described in the Bible. While some believe they're Enoch and Elijah (since neither died) or unnamed future individuals, I present evidence they are Moses and Elijah—Moses because the witnesses turn water to blood and call down plagues like he did in Egypt, and Elijah because they shut up the sky preventing rain, call down fire from Heaven, and Malachi predicts Elijah's return before the great day of the Lord. Regarding timing, though many place their ministry in the first half of the Tribulation, I lean toward the second half because the temple trampling (42 months) and their prophesying (1,260 days) are mentioned consecutively with the same time period, and the Seventh Trumpet sounds immediately after their ministry ends.

title: Ukraine’s Spider's Web Attack | Marking the End Times
description:
Today, I examine Ukraine's shocking "Spider's Web" drone attack against four Russian airfields—being called the most audacious military operation in history. Using 117 inexpensive toy-like drones costing just hundreds of dollars each, Ukraine inflicted $7 billion in damage to Russian strategic assets, including nuclear bombers located 2,500 miles from the Ukrainian border. This humiliating blow to Russia has redefined modern warfare and demonstrates how cheap drone technology could revolutionize future conflicts. I explore how the wounded Russian bear may become more dangerous and aggressive, potentially accelerating the prophetic timeline toward the Gog and Magog invasion of Ezekiel 38-39. This attack may be Russia's Pearl Harbor, but ultimately points toward Israel's future Pearl Harbor.

In the second part of this episode, I address four important subscriber questions about end-times prophecy. The first concerns the timing of the Two Witnesses in Revelation 11 and how they can witness during the Tribulation's second half if killed midway through. I explain that I place their ministry in the second half based on the parallel 42-month timeline with the Temple's trampling. Another subscriber asks whether Jesus raised a fourth person from the dead, referencing the mysterious young man in Mark 14:51. I clarify that Scripture records only three resurrections by Jesus, and that passage likely describes Mark himself fleeing. A third question explores whether AI could embody the Antichrist. I firmly explain that Scripture portrays the Antichrist as a literal human being who will use technology extensively but isn't technology itself. Finally, someone asks about the current location of deceased believers' souls. I teach that believers' souls immediately enter Christ's presence upon death while their bodies await future resurrection and glorification at the rapture.

title: The Ancient Gaza Prophecy | Marking the End Times
description:
In this episode, I examine Israel’s stunning announcement to call up 
thousands of reservists with plans to capture Gaza and occupy it 
indefinitely. As Israel’s security cabinet approves this dramatic escalation 
ahead of President Trump’s mid-May Middle East visit, I explore the 
prophetic implications through the lens of Zephaniah 2:4–7. This 2,600-
year-old prophecy specifically mentions Gaza being abandoned and the 
coastline becoming “pastures with shepherds’ caves” for “the remnant of 
the house of Judah.” While I don’t believe in double fulfillment of 
prophecies, I see what’s happening today as a powerful foreshadow of 
Zephaniah’s vision—just as the Babylonian invasion in his day prefigured 
the ultimate Day of the Lord. With Israel planning to “flatten any buildings 
that remain standing” and displace Gaza’s population to a humanitarian 
area, we may be witnessing a modern parallel to ancient prophecy—a 
precursor to the final Day of the Lord and the restoration of Israel in the 
Millennial Kingdom.
Our Q&A segment addresses several intriguing biblical questions. One 
viewer wonders why both the Rapture and Christ’s return after the 
Tribulation are referred to as the “Second Coming,” creating potential 
confusion about the timeline of prophetic events. Another question explores 
the 200 million-strong army mentioned in Revelation 9:16 and whether they 
might initially come to war against the Beast rather than serving him. We 
also received a historical inquiry about the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half 
the tribe of Manasseh who stayed east of the Jordan River, asking if their 
descendants remain there today. Finally, two fascinating questions relate to

dates between Artaxerxes’ decree and Jesus’ Triumphal Entry, and how to 
reconcile what appears to be a mathematical discrepancy in the 483-year

title: Why I Am a Pre-Millennialist | Marking the End Times
description:
In this week’s program, I begin a special two-part series explaining why I 
believe in pre-millennialism and why I think you should too. I outline the 
three main views of the Millennium – amillennialism, postmillennialism, and
premillennialism – and explain their key differences. While all three views 
agree that Jesus is King and will return to judge the earth, they differ on the
timing and nature of Christ’s Reign. I present the first two reasons from my 
“PRE-MIL,” an acronym I use to explain why pre-millennialism is the most 
biblically sound position: P stands for “Promises of God” (only pre-
millennialism allows for the literal fulfillment of God’s Covenants with 
Abraham and David), and R represents “Retribution against the false 
trinity” (it makes more sense that God deals with the Antichrist, False 
Prophet, and Satan in sequence). In the second part, I’ll continue with the 
remaining four points of this important biblical teaching.

Today’s questions cover the following: Whether the “little horn” in Daniel 
refers to the Antichrist being physically small); clarify the 70 weeks 
prophecy in Daniel 9; discuss the potential casualties from the Rapture; 
explore whether non-believers will hear the trumpet and archangel’s voice 
at the Rapture: and explain how people saved during the Millennium will be

In our Revelation study, I examine the first four Trumpet Judgments in

title: Antichrist Temple Prophecies Unveiled | Marking the End Times
description:
In today’s program, I explore the fascinating connection between the 
coming Antichrist and the future Third Temple that will be built on 
Jerusalem’s Temple Mount. Drawing from my recent studies in Exodus 
about the Tabernacle, I share insights about the Ark of the Covenant—that 
sacred wooden chest topped with golden cherubim where God’s presence 
was enthroned in the Holy of Holies. This background sets up a powerful 
revelation from 2 Thessalonians 2, where Scripture tells us the Antichrist 
will “take his seat in the temple of God.” The implications are striking: this 
coming world leader will commit the ultimate blasphemy by usurping God’s 
very throne on earth. Whether the original Ark is recovered from beneath 
the Temple Mount or a replica is built, the Antichrist will declare himself 
superior to the God of Israel from the very spot where God’s presence once 
dwelt.
The second portion of our program continues our ongoing exposition of the 
book of Revelation, focusing on the great multitude of Gentile believers 
described in chapter 7:9–17. Unlike the precisely numbered 144,000 Jewish 
witnesses, this innumerable multitude represents Gentiles from every 
nation saved during the Tribulation—likely through the evangelistic efforts 
of those 144,000 sealed Jews. Their presence in Heaven, clothed in white 
robes and holding palm branches, reveals God’s mercy even amid judgment.
I emphasize that while many will come to faith after the Rapture, waiting to 
trust Christ is extremely dangerous—both because we don’t know when 
we’ll die and because salvation will be much harder during that terrible 
time. These Tribulation martyrs, having “washed their robes in the blood of 
the Lamb,” remind us of our responsibility to believe and appropriate what 
Christ has done for us.

title: From Tanks to Horses | Marking the End Times
description:
In today’s episode, I discuss an astonishing development in the Russia-
Ukraine conflict that caught my attention. Russia has begun using horses, 
camels, and donkeys to transport troops and supplies due to the depletion 
of their military equipment—the largest in 80 years. I analyze how this 
connects to Ezekiel 38’s prophecy of the Gog-Magog invasion, which 
describes soldiers on horseback using ancient weapons. This addresses a 
common question about end-times prophecy: Why would modern armies use
primitive transportation? I explore three interpretations: (1) that Ezekiel 
used terms his audience could understand, (2) that nations might revert to 
archaic methods due to resource depletion, or (3) that the rise of drone 
warfare might render expensive tanks obsolete. Whatever the explanation, 
all prophesied nations are currently in place for this future invasion.
The second part of the program continues our ongoing exposition of 
Revelation, focusing on chapter 7:1–8 and the mysterious 144,000. I explain
how this passage answers the question posed at the end of chapter 6: “Who 
is able to stand?” during God’s wrath. These 144,000 are literally Jewish 
men—12,000 from each of the twelve tribes—who will be sealed by God for 
protection during the Tribulation. I clarify common misconceptions, 
explaining they are not Seventh-day Adventists, Jehovah’s Witnesses, or 
symbolic of the Church. God will use these men as powerful evangelists
—”144,000 Billy Grahams”—to reach countless Gentiles. This demonstrates 
God’s faithfulness to preserve the Jewish people throughout history and His 
continuing work of salvation even during earth’s darkest hour. These sealed 
Jews will fulfill Jesus’ prophecy that the gospel will be preached to all 
nations before the end.

title: Peace Before the Storm | Marking the End Times
description:
Today I want to challenge a common misconception about the End Times—
that the world will be in chaos when the Rapture occurs. In light of the 
remarkable peace negotiations happening around Russia-Ukraine and 
Israel-Hamas conflicts, we need to revisit what the Bible actually tells us. In 
1 Thessalonians 5:1–3 Paul reveals that the Tribulation will begin when 
people are saying “peace and safety.” This means that rather than expecting
global turmoil before the Rapture, we might actually see unprecedented 
peace efforts succeeding. The world could be living under the delusion that 
all is well when Christ suddenly returns for His Church. These current 
peace negotiations may be setting the stage for that brief period of false 
security before the Tribulation judgments begin.
In our Q&A portion, I address several thoughtful questions from 
subscribers. I explain the historical development of our BC/AD dating 
system and why Bible chronology appears to “count backward.” I 
recommend resources for those wanting to study the Bible more effectively 
despite not being avid readers. I also tackle a question about the pre-wrath 
Rapture view compared to the pre-Tribulation position, explaining why the 
entire seven-year Tribulation constitutes God's wrath. Finally, I clarify 
prophecies regarding Damascus and Elam (modern Iran), distinguishing 
between historical fulfillments and potential future events.

He was born and raised in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. He attended Oklahoma State University and graduated from law school in 1984. After working for a judge at the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals for four years, Mark was led to attend Dallas Theological Seminary, graduating in 1991. He completed his PhD at Dallas Theological Seminary in 2005 and serves as an associate professor of Bible exposition at DTS.  Mark and his wife, Cheryl, live in Edmond, Oklahoma. They have two sons, Justin (married to Natalee) and Samuel, and two grandchildren.
